reviewText:
This is an awesome puzzle game for two or more people. It will certainly test your friendship or marriage, lol. At first glance, I questioned if there was enough game here to merit the pricetag, but oh boy is there. There are tons of levels, and even a puzzle generator where you can alter various puzzle dynamics. The levels increase in difficulty nicely.

There is a manual that you print out, and you are free to study it as much as you want. One person works with the bomb - they are the only ones that are allowed to see the screen. The other person(s) is using the manual as a tool to help you solve the puzzles on the bomb. It is helpful to play with more than two people - we had an extra person and you could divvy out puzzles to save time. The average time they give you to solve a bomb is 5 minutes.

Pros:
+Awesome fresh take on a co-op puzzle game
+Puzzles are really well done - it would take a long time to 'memorize' the manual or be an expert at this game
+Lots of room for future DLC (ie. a new manual version, game modes, etc.)
+Controls are minimal and work well

Cons:
-I am not certain that you could complete every bomb with just two people
-I prefer this in short bursts rather than long play sessions
-People seem to have strong opinions on which role they like playing - for example, I literally refuse to be the expert with the manual. Thankfully my friends want that role, and they refuse to run the computer. That could be a factor.

Totally worth the money - I will certainly be toying with this for a long time.

reviewText:
Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes
A little game where you and your friends are disarming bombs.

This is a co-op game that puts you, the player, alone in a room with nothing but a bomb, and sometimes an annoying alarm clock. You must disarm the bomb before the timer on said bomb runs out. How ever, you have no manual. In comes the co-op mechanic as your friends have a manual that they can use to instruct you on how to disarm the bomb. This is a game where your friendships will either solidify, or very likely yourself, blow up to pieces.

The bomb you're given has modules which take the form of various puzzles that you must solve and complete in order to disarm the bomb. You can have up to eleven modules in total that range in difficulty. You will have to trust your partners to decipher the information you're giving them. They must be able to use that information and read what the manual instructs before finally giving you the instructions you need to disarm the bomb before it disarms you.

To conclude, this is an incredibly fun game. Co-Op done absolutely right. It also comes with Oculus Rift support. Pick this game up, you will not be disappointed. If you don't want to disarm the bomb but love giving instructions, the manual is absolutely free to use via the link below.

Bomb Manual. [www.bombmanual.com]

reviewText:
I will review this from two points of view: As gamer, and as an ESL teacher. At the time of reviewing this I have only 30 minutes played, but my experience with this game goes beyond my own account.

Gamer:
If you're looking for an epic single player dungeon crawler like Skyrim or Witcher, look elsewhere. If you're looking for a guns-blazing experience like CoD or Battlefield, look elsewhere. If you're looking for a slow, calm strategic game for the family like Monopoly, look elsewhere.
What you will find here is a unique experience that other games cannot deliver.
-Communication and trust are key. They are more necessary in this simple game than in any military shooter or other co-op experience that you will find.
-There is also a small bit of strategy that plays into the game; do you tell you friend(s) about the easy modules first, or the hard one? Do you use your own memorized knowlegde of the manual to save some time, or rely on the expert that has the manual in hand?
-A single mistake, even in the early levels, can cause panic. Some of the multi-stage modules will reset to the beginning if you make a mistake. My wife and I played this game together. She had the manual. We had over a minute left. It was a module that requires you to remember numbers and positions. We were on the second to last step, and I made a mistake. We stayed calm and kept going. Step three, she read the wrong instructions. One chance left. Thirty seconds. I'm almost shouting the numbers. Fifteen seconds. She's reading too slow. Last stage. I say the number. Time: five seconds. She starts reading the instructions. I can't... I push the button. An explosion rocks our living room. Moments before we had been calm and collected, and in the final two seconds I panicced and pushed a random button.
-Replayability; Even playing through the same levels with a different friend can be exciting. Once you're tired of that, there's a free play mode that allows you to customize the game to your liking. Make it as hard or easy as you like. Want to give yourself thirty seconds to solve 11 modules with no extra chances if you make a mistake? It's your funeral, but you can.
-Party play; Break this game out during a party or dinner with friends and you'll have an extremely exciting experience.


ESL Teacher (Adult students)
I'm always looking outside the classroom for things that can help improve the learning experience. This game has extremely high potential. Once students have reached an appropriate level of fluency, this game will provide a tense situation in which they will need to work together outside their own language. Considering the bomb manual is in English, translating the instructions back into their native tongue will only slow them down. I will definitely use this in my classroom to provide an interesting alternative to drilling vocabulary.

reviewText:
What would you do if your life depended on somebody else? You had to trust everything they said and follow their instructions exactly. Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes takes this concept and makes it hilarious and fun. The concept is devilishly simple in design, one player defuses the bomb, another player has the instructions of how to defuse it. Neither of them can see what the other is doing. Communication is absolutely integral to the gameplay of this title. Psychologist will probably use this game to stress test people. This is as much of a social experiment as it is a clever puzzle game. Visually, Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes is rather simple, nothing to fancy but it does look good. The music on other hand does get more violent and intense as the timer begins to run down. Adding to the delicious stress and tension. Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes is an amazing example of thinking outside the box and typical gaming conventions. This is why I love Indie Games this is the type of innovation that Triple A developers would never dare to try. There is excellent design here, no bugs, and something anyone can play. The only gripe I could muster is that the person giving the instructions might not have as much fun as the bomb defuser.  Otherwise this is a great game and easily worth your attention, time, and money!

reviewText:
An hour into the game and I can already see it overtaking Monopoly as the king of games for which victory is sweeter than wine, and friendships are almost assured to be ruined.

If you have good communication skills and can iron out a strict set of rules for communicating the relevant information about the bomb with whomever is reading the manual, then your life is going to be just fine. My boyfriend and I have breezed through the first ten stages or so, and are quite honestly flabbergasted at how stupid some of the manual-readers are in the various YouTube videos we've watched.

More than anything, it's important to keep a cool head. If your manual-reader or manual-readers screw up and you end up getting a strike, it's not going to do you any good to get angry with them - if anything, it will just make them more nervous and more likely to screw up a second or third time during the same run.

That having been said, the game also has various ways in which it likes to give you a swift kick in the stones when it comes to rattling your nerves: There's a desk clock sitting next to you, and from time to time it likes to set off its alarm mid-mission. If you happen to be spectacularly unlucky, the game will cut power to the lights for a few seconds, leaving you in the darkness. No, don't turn up the brightness on your monitor to compensate. That's cheating.

Overall, I have to say that the game is great fun, and I'd love to play even more of it, but my boyfriend is boycotting his role as manual-reader for the rest of the evening due to his nerves being completely wrecked. Hopefully I can get a group together this weekend to play it some more.

I love this game, perfect for playing over skype with friends that have the manual.  You and the people you're working with will quickly develop a set of things to be looking for, fast solutions, and a vocabulary unique to the group. Do be forewarned that this game can be stressful and hectic, but cathartic when the puzzle is completed. I cannot recommend this game for people who don't handle stress well or have a heart condition so take it with a grain of salt that I find this game fun. The random nature of the modules and the time limit aren't your only obstacles, an alarm on the desk can go off making communication with your team difficult, the lights can go out without warning and may or may not come back on, as well as modules that need to be regularly interacted with, a limited number of mistakes that can even be removed entirely meaning your first mistake is your last, and various other parts of interest on the bomb that can change how each module is disarmed.

Do you love puzzles? Do you love communicating what you can see to people that cannot? Do you love being under a time crunch that challenges you to be clear and concise while trusting your friends to communicate back to you?
Then Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes is perfect for you.
Are you easily distracted, easily stressed out, or have a heart condition that is exacerbated by being stressed out?
Avoid this game like the plague!

Both you and your team will get frustrated early and often, the twenty-three page manual is clear but difficult to work through without a physical copy in front of you, but once the modules are solved and the bomb is disarmed you and your team feel fantastic as the tension and stress are all released.

Most people have probably heard of Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes (abbreviated as KTANE) and watched someone else play it in Youtube or Twitch. Most of these people would have also played along with other people who owned KTANE because only one copy of the game is required for an entire party to play, which is awesome.

At this point, these people can't help but to buy their own copy of the game because of the sheer amount of fun it offers. So what exactly makes this game fun?

Well first of all, there is a timed bomb involved. Only one person (the bomb defuser) gets to disarm it while the rest of his friends (the bomb experts) will try to help him based on a bomb manual. The catch is: only the bomb defuser is allowed to see the bomb, and only the bomb experts are allowed to look at the manual. That makes communication an integral part of KTANE, making it an excellent social party game.

Now I will share my personal experience with this game as well. When I got my siblings to play KTANE with me, I didn't carry any high expectations at first. My younger brother and sister hardly ever liked the same games as I do. Whenever I try to get them to play a game with me, they were clearly uninterested. But when I bought KTANE and convinced them to try it out together, they played it and agreed that it was thrilling. Soon, as we're disarming bombs like a real team, I realised how exciting it is to find a common game where everyone plays a role in it.

The game is definitely worth the price, so go ahead and grab the game if you can find a group of people to play with. There's a saying that goes time plus tragedy equals comedy". And since this game is all about timed bombs

reviewText:
Good ideas don’t necessarily have to be created in some laboratory or a huge studio. They don’t require a tremendous amount of money and time spent. Sometimes all it takes is a weekend and a huge coffee supply. For Steel Crate Games that weekend was Global Game Jam 2014, where they made a concept for an Oculus Rift game where only one player sees what’s happening on screen.

Luckily, the final version of Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes doesn’t require any kind of virtual reality set, but it still needs one very important component – co-players. The game is impossible to play solo and you’ll need at least one more person in the same room, or the next room if shouting across the apartment is ok with you, or if all else fails, an online co-player who you can talk to through a VOIP service.

Keep Talking and Nobody Explodes is a game you simply must try out, it’s both a video game and a social game, and simultaneously a test for reflexes and concentration. No video in the world can possibly convey the exact feeling you get while playing – frantically going through pages with schemes and directions or waiting for your co-players to come up with a solution while there’s only seconds left on the timer. Get your copy, call your friends, neighbors and colleagues, print out the manual and dig into one of the most exciting co-op experiences of all time. And keep talking, never stop talking. Because if you keep talking nobody will explode.

Full review here: http://play-zine.com/2015/11/keep-talking-and-nobody-explodes/

reviewText:
Rating - 8/10

WOW.  This game is the best cooperative game I've ever downloaded, bar none.

Defusing bombs while another reads the instructions sounds simple, and it is - at first.  We're playing through the story mode that slowly ramps up the difficulty, and every time it's a new challenge.  Having a paper manual as the second player's only resource really brings more tension; there's something unnerving about listening to papers rustle when the clock is ticking down.  The music is fitting, the visuals are simple but effective.  The controls are intuitive and don't require much adjustment on the part of the active player.  I can see why it's becoming a popular game to break out at parties, but I would advise against playing under the influence of ANYTHING - you will need as much concentration and mental acuity as you can muster.  Once you hit a certain threshhold, the game will try to distract you, and the puzzles will be harder to solve - both harder to describe and harder to complete.

My husband and I are excellent communicators and don't hold grudges easily - we did awesome.  Not every group will fare so well.  This is a potential friendship killer, but it's a great way to build communication and trust skills with the people you know will walk away as friends; even if you did blow them up a few times.

Final rating - 8/10:  Needs the right co-op players, but totally worth it!

Keep Talking and Nobody explodes is an assymetrical Co-Op only (i mean you can solo it though if you have a stupid good memory... or if you cheat and use your own manual) Puzzle game where one person is tasked with disarming a live, randomly generated modular bomb, and their friends are tasked with walking them through the process of each step with a physical, and very intricately crafted bomb defusing manual.

And unlike extremely limiting party games like Towerfall and Gang Beasts, to which you are limited to having your play partners in the same room, this game can be played over long distances as long as one has access to voice chat, the .pdf file, and the game itself (only one copy is needed).

I think that's one of the things that stands out. With this harebrained, arrogant, and contradictory resurgence of local multiplayer games (because the internet and online play is way more readily available to most), KTANE stands out among the rest with its ease of accessibility over online mediums.

But I digress. This bomb defusing game is stressful, intense, and loads of fun. I hope to god this isn't milked at all though. Let's keep the concept fresh and clean, yeah?

reviewText:
Keep Talking and Nobody explodes is an assymetrical Co-Op only (i mean you can solo it though if you have a stupid good memory... or if you cheat and use your own manual) Puzzle game where one person is tasked with disarming a live, randomly generated modular bomb, and their friends are tasked with walking them through the process of each step with a physical, and very intricately crafted bomb defusing manual.

This has got to be THE MOST original concept i've seen for a game in years. And unlike extremely limiting party games like Towerfall and Gang Beasts, to which you are limited to having your play partners in the same room, this game can be played over long distances as long as one has access to voice chat, the .pdf file, and the game itself (only one copy is needed).

I think that's one of the things that stands out. With this harebrained, arrogant, and contradictory resurgence of local multiplayer games (because the internet and online play is way more readily available to most), KTANE stands out among the rest with its ease of accessibility over online mediums.

But I digress. This bomb defusing game is stressful, intense, and loads of fun. I hope to god this isn't milked at all though. Let's keep the concept fresh and clean, yeah?

10/10 will refuse to learn morse code again.

It's a great social game that puts your ability to communicate to the test. The difficulty curve is set up so that early on, when you need to learn to how best express information about the bomb, there are only a few simple tasks to work out. This gives you the time you need to work things out. As everyone becomes more acquainted with how things work, the bombs get harder and the focus shifts to efficiency and effectiveness of your communication. The time pressure gets harder to deal with, and that keeps the game interesting.

reviewText: TooOnTo's In-Depth Reviews!\n\nKeep Talking and Nobody Explodes (KTaNE) is an amazing co-operative game. Unless you're looking to memorize the manual, a friend is needed to play this game. On the bomb their are modules that you need to disarm to defuse he bomb. Their are strikes on the bomb, meaning you can only fail 2 times without the bomb exploding, but the timer speeds up on those first 2 times. The communication aspect of this game is better than any other. The game is as complex and simple as it needs to be. Some modules are hard for the defuer to understand, and some are hard for the expert to understand. One of my least favorite modules is Morse Code. I am giving this game a negative review despite having a lot of fun with it because the game was very glitchy when I played it.

The issues:
1) The game always went nearly solid black at the beginning of each game, and stayed black until alt-tabbing.
2) The game often would not take mouse input.

us: cut the last wire!!
them: I can't, I don't know how.
us: idiot! its so easy, just click it.
them (frusterated): I AM!! The game doesn't work, nothing works... The bomb just exploded guys...

This happened for two attempts until we finally decided to investigate. Turns out the game was not taking any mouse input. Some input worked, like you could choose menu's etc, but you could not manipulate the bomb in any way (click, rotate etc).

To fix we had to Alt-tab. The full screen of black was also fixed by alt-tabbing. It was not clear when this issue would happen so often during game play we would need to alt-tab out of the game and then back in. The requirement to do this was too tedious for the non-computer savvy players and so it forced only one player to be the bomb defuser.

A game with a near perfect score should not have such a debilitating issue.

We played on a Surface Pro. We played last weekend 11/14/2015.
I see a patch came out recently that fixed issues with incorrect resolutions. I have not played the game since to see if it was responsible for these issues.

The basics:  The one at the PC (they have Mac version too, doesn't take much horse power) has the Bomb in front of them and can twist and turn it about to see everything about it.

We tried it out last night: My GF on  the laptop and I flipped the pages of the book.   We failed on the very first bomb due to a failure to communicate about the number and color of the wires :)  After that it got a lot smoother.

Not only does getting more familiar with our roles help, but  we also got better at relaying the important information faster!   We joked about that, being as I'm an IT guy and She's a 911 call taker...

Definately look forward all the future rounds!

reviewText:
Great game!

This game is tough to classify. It's a kind of assisted-reality multi-player game that makes players work together to diffuse a bomb. The bomb is displayed and manipulated with a PC and is to be seen only by the player in the diffuser" role while the other players use physical documentation to discover and relay information necessary for diffusing the bomb back to the diffuser. I played this game with 3 friends and rotated in and out of the "diffuser" role. We opted to just use a laptop rather than the Oculus DK2 we had available.

You could write a thesis on social interaction based on observing people play this game. It's absolutely fascinating to watch players go from being overwhelmed by the manual to becoming the "experts" the game assumes they are by title. The puzzles or "modules" as they're shown in-game translate very well to the information in the manual and served up many Ah-ha moments from both the diffuser and the experts. Quite a bit more replay-ability than I expected due to a good learning curve. I HIGHLY recommend this game."
